library.name: A Comprehensive Bibliography on Syriac Studies

bib: Lund, Jerome Alan. “An Overlooked Definition of the Ethpeel of the Verb ܫܠܡ in Syriac.” Journal of Semitic Studies 67:2 (2022): 547–61. https://doi.org/https://doi.org/10.1093/jss/fgac004.
citation: Jerome Alan Lund, “An Overlooked Definition of the Ethpeel of the Verb ܫܠܡ in Syriac,” Journal of Semitic Studies 67:2 (2022): 547–61, https://doi.org/https://doi.org/10.1093/jss/fgac004.

data.title: An Overlooked Definition of the Ethpeel of the Verb ܫܠܡ in Syriac
data.abstractNote: The Ethpeel of the verb graphic normally functions as the passive of the Aphel in the language of the Peshitta Old Testament and means ‘be delivered up, handed over to’ and the like. It is therefore not strange that translators of Isaiah and Psalms in the Antioch Bible have rendered it accordingly, even within contexts where it would be awkward to do so. This article will argue that the Ethpeel of graphic has another meaning, overlooked by the lexicographers of Syriac, one that is related to the Peal. In some contexts, it will be argued, the Ethpeel of graphic means ‘be like, similar to’.
